articles.title: About me
articles.contents:
I am interested in natural climate solutions, particularly regenerative agriculture. I am also passionate about education and mentorship. My current projects include helping White Buffalo Land Trust gain financial value from their regenerative farming operation through ecosystem services credits, visualizing a dataset on cookstove use in Ghana for policymakers to interact with, and guiding youth on rite of passage backpacking trips in Yosemite with Back to Earth.
I started working on climate issues in 2012 when I helped start successful fossil fuel divestment campaigns at Pomona College (where I went to undergrad) and Pitzer College. After exploring other sustainability sectors and graduating in 2015, I found a way to combine social justice and environmental stewardship by helping cities develop equitable climate adaptation and mitigation strategies from 2016 to 2021.
I am now pursuing a Master’s degree at the Bren School of UCSB, where I am using my background in climate action and multidisciplinary problem solving to advance natural climate solutions.
